entry.title: ‚ÄòStop the 21st century atrocity‚Äô in Gaza, Fletcher urges UN Security Council
entry.summary: No aid has entered Gaza for more than 10 weeks and every single one of the 2.1 million people there faces famine conditions, the UN Emergency Relief Coordinator Tom Fletcher said on Tuesday in a briefing to the Security Council in New York.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Half of women‚Äôs organizations in crisis zones risk closure within six months
entry.summary: Women‚Äôs organisations operating in crisis settings are being pushed to the brink by widespread funding cuts. In a report published on Tuesday, UN Women ‚Äì the UN agency for gender equality ‚Äì warned that 47 per cent of these groups may be forced to close within the next six months.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: GAZA LIVE: 'Humanity, the law and reason must prevail' in Gaza, UN relief chief tells Security Council
entry.summary: The Security Council is meeting in New York to discuss the horror of Gaza, where humanitarians warn of ‚Äúa critical risk of famine‚Äù and aid shipments have been blocked by Israel for over 70 days. UN relief chief Tom Fletcher briefed the Security Council, asking ambassadors if they will act decisively "to prevent genocide" and ensure respect for international law. He also called on Hamas to release all hostages and stop putting civilians at risk. Follow live for key updates from UN Headquarters and reports from the region. App users can follow coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: US deportations raise serious human rights concerns
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights High Commissioner Volker T√ºrk has voiced concern over the recent deportation of large numbers of non-nationals from the United States, particularly to third countries.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Number of internally displaced breaks new record with no let-up in conflicts, disasters
entry.summary: A record 83.4 million people have been forced from their homes around the world, fuelled by an increase in disasters and conflict, the UN migration agency, IOM, said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As funding cuts bite, UN chief announces new dawn for peacekeeping
entry.summary: The future of peacekeeping took centre stage on Tuesday in Berlin as UN chief Ant√≥nio Guterres urged Member States to do more to support the global body‚Äôs 'blue helmets' and stave off the worst impacts of deep funding cuts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: 57 children reported dead from malnutrition, says WHO
entry.summary: In the aid desert of Gaza, malnourished children are dying while survivors can now expect a lifetime of dire health problems, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN aviation council finds Russia responsible for downing of Malaysian Airlines flight
entry.summary: A UN body has found that Russia was responsible for the 17 July 2014 downing of Malaysian Airlines flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine that killed all 298 people on board.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tariff timeline with China, so far
entry.summary: The U.S. and China put a semi-hold on tariffs for the next 90‚Ä¶ Tags: China, New York Times, tariff

entry.title: English wine is on the rise. Here is where to experience it
entry.summary:
Domaine Evremond, established by Taittinger, produces Chardonnay, Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier vines on its south-facing slopes in Kent. Savour the best of English wine with new festivals and vineyard experiences.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There was a time, not so long ago really, when English oenophiles looking to set up shop had no choice but to relocate to the balmier climes of France or Italy. Not anymore. A changing climate, a culture of experimentation and greater awareness of which regions are best suited to grape growing have combined to make England one of Europe‚Äôs most exciting viticultural destinations ‚Äî and it shows. Across the country, you‚Äôll find tours and tastings that showcase some of England‚Äôs best homegrown producers. ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Alcohol is killing more women than ever before
entry.summary:
Jasmine Charbonier‚Äôs heavy drinking started in college. By her early 30s, she was downing up to eight tequila cocktails daily, several days each week. A few years ago she tried to quit and was surprised when she plummeted into withdrawal.
Research shows that while men are still more likely to die from an alcohol-related disease, the gap is narrowing. The most recent figures, published in 2024, found deaths in women have risen at a rate of 35 percent, while men increased just 27 percent.
(8 things we've learned about how alcohol harms the body.)
The rise in deaths results from an unfortunate gender equality: Women now raise their glass almost as frequently as men. A recent U.S. government survey found 45 percent of women drank in the prior month, compared to 50 percent of men‚Ä¶

entry.title: The secret program that brought Nazi scientists to the U.S.
entry.summary:
On July 20, 1969, a crew of American astronauts successfully landed on the moon for the first time. Though only three of them were in the spacecraft, thousands of people had contributed their brainpower to put the astronauts in flight.
Among the contributors: German scientists who had been members of the Nazi Party. The United States recruited them in the years after World War II¬†under a federal program called Operation Paperclip.¬†
The program remains a controversial chapter in American history, when U.S. officials incorporated former Nazis into American life and institutions. Here‚Äôs how Operation Paperclip got off the ground.
In the spring of 1945, Allied forces were closing in on Nazi Germany, and the end of the war in Europe was in sight. Officials started to make p‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 ways to find calm in Thailand's larger-than-life capital city
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Bangkok may have a reputation as one of the world‚Äôs biggest concrete jungles, but in between the neon-lit streets, rooftop bars and crowded markets there are some glorious pockets of calm. The city‚Äôs network of canals help create breathing space among the tuk-tuk packed neighbourhoods, and there‚Äôs a surprising amount of green space in the city‚Äôs environs ‚Äî accessible by boat, bike or on foot. Here are eight of our favourite hideaways.¬†
One of several plush hotels lining the Chao Phraya River, the Riva Arun is noteworthy for its peaceful, top-floor terrace restaurant, Above Riva. You can ease into the day with breakfast or settle in for sunset cocktails, watching boats crisscross the river. The dinner menu goes b‚Ä¶

The APIÔºå which has evolved through five preview iterationsÔºå aims to simplify and provide developers with clearerÔºå safer frameworks for managing parallel tasksÔºå particularly when working with virtual threads. Developers now open a scope through static factory methodsÔºå such as `StructuredTaskScope.open()`Ôºå a change that clarifies defaults and paves the way for richer completion policies. Each fork launches a subtaskÔºå by default on a virtual threadÔºå returning a `Subtask` handle whose `get()` is safe only after `join()` completes. üìä ÊñáÁ´†‰ø°ÊÅØ

entry.title: Traveling during hurricane season? Here's what you should know
entry.summary:
Tropical cyclones are unpredictable so being prepared and knowing your options in case of a storm are key when travelling during hurricane season. From what to pack to whether travel insurance will cover you, here‚Äôs what you need to know about travelling during tropical cyclones.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Long balmy days, sparkling turquoise waters ‚Äî these are the classic ingredients of a tropical break. But risk going during the hurricane season and you could end up looking at a very different picture. It doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean trips have to be off the agenda though. In fact, for some, off-season prices and the lack of crowds make hurricane season a particularly attractive time to travel. Here‚Äôs how best to prepare.
Collective‚Ä¶

entry.title: Join a homegrown family feast in Italy's Basilicata region
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Deft and swift, she forms millimetre-thick sheets, slicing them into ribbons that she wraps around her narrow rolling pin to shape the screw-like ss√´ppondap√≤rt√´ (the word for ‚Äòdoor hinge pin‚Äô in local dialect) or cuts into the roughly square-shaped takk√´nu√®dd√´. Next, the remaining dough ‚Äî an egg-free mix of semolina flour and 00 pasta flour ‚Äî is divided and rolled into thin sausages. She cuts these into one- and two-finger-width pieces and presses them into cavatelli and orecchiette, her digits moving in a blur of speed. Maria Coppola Colucci has been working in the kitchen at this pace for two hours and the septuagenarian grandmother shows no sign of flagging.
‚ÄúWe were in the garden first thing this morning diggin‚Ä¶

entry.title: Field of Dreams: Football Breathes Life into Yemen‚Äôs Camps
entry.summary: Every summer in Ma‚Äôrib, Yemen, a place marked by loss and uncertainty, a football tournament offers a rare kind of hope. For hundreds of displaced youth living across more than a dozen sites, it‚Äôs a chance to unite, to belong, and to dream.

entry.title: Try this budget alternative to Canada's famous Rocky Mountaineer
entry.summary:
Completed in 1914 as the western end of the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway, the Skeena travels through some of British Columbia‚Äôs wildest backcountry, including the 24,700sq mile Great Bear Rainforest, the largest temperate forest on Earth. Crossing vast tracts of British Columbian wilderness, the Skeena is one of Canada‚Äôs most thrilling, and little-known, rail journeys.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúLadies and gentlemen, we‚Äôll be making an unscheduled stop here to pick up another passenger,‚Äù announces train manager Alain Vermette. ‚ÄúIn fact, we need to back up. We just missed his stop.‚Äù
Brakes squeal and gears grind as Via Rail Line 6 ‚Äî better known as ‚Äòthe Skeena‚Äô ‚Äî slows, shifts into reverse and trundles back down the track. A minute l‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to see wildlife in Europe this summer
entry.summary:
Summer is the best time for wildlife-watching in Europe and spotting animals such as bears, wolves and lynx, is made possible thanks to knowledgable guides and various animal reintroduction schemes. From the FƒÉgƒÉra»ô Mountains of Romania to the teeming sea cliffs of St Kilda in Scotland, Europe is still home to staggering displays of summer wildlife. Whether you‚Äôre searching for sperm whales, brown bears, dolphins or wolves, here are six of the best destinations to target.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Although quite densely populated, Europe isn‚Äôt short of lonely island outposts, remote mountain ranges and dark, seemingly impenetrable forests ‚Äî and many of them shelter world-class displays of animal activity. You‚Äôll need to be well-equipped‚Ä¶

entry.title: Whatever happened to the samurai?
entry.summary:
The samurai, Japan‚Äôs celebrated lineage of warriors, emerged in the Heian period (794-1185), when the rise of their status enabled them to mingle with the refined nobility living in the then-capital of Heian-ky≈ç (Kyoto). Samurai fought in the ≈ånin War and during the period of unrest that followed. From then on, the bushi, as the samurai were also called, made their mark on Japanese history with their exceptional fighting prowess, becoming emblematic of Japanese culture.
The high point of samurai history is often associated with the Tokugawa shogunate, also known as the Edo period (1603‚Äì1868), a time of peace, prosperity, isolationist policies, and cultural growth. This is the most studied era of Japanese history and the period in which novelists, filmmakers, and comic book creators te‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is the longest hiking trail in Central Asia
entry.summary:
Tourists prepare for a boating adventure on K√∂l-Suu (or Kel-Suu), a lake located in the heart of the Tian Shan mountain range in Kyrgyzstan. By summer's end, more than 600 miles will be added to the Kyrgyz Nomad Trail, granting hikers access to lesser-known parts of the country.
Adventurous hikers now have access to see a different side of Kyrgyzstan. The¬†Kyrgyz Nomad Trail¬†(KNT) is a 1,243-mile (2,000-kilometer) long-distance hiking trail in northern and eastern Kyrgyzstan, which make it the longest trail network in Central Asia. Launched in June 2024, the KNT‚Äîa network of 18 marked sections‚Äîruns west to east passing through states (oblasts) such as Jalal-Abad, Naryn, and Issyk-Kul.
Along the trail, hikers also experience¬†the beauty of Kyrgyzstan¬†firsthand with natural landma‚Ä¶

entry.title: Do chimpanzees have rhythm? Listen to their drumming.
entry.summary:
Chimpanzees drum and make calls to communicate. Two new studies have found they drum to send message across large distances and can create complex vocalizations. New research on the rhythmic drumming and complex calls of chimpanzees could point scientists to the origins of language.
‚ÄúYou feel it in your body when they drum‚Äîit‚Äôs insanely impressive,‚Äù says Vesta Eleuteri.¬†
She‚Äôs a cognitive biologist at the University of Vienna who studies chimpanzee drumming and observed over 350 drumming performances like this in five African countries.
Chimpanzees in West Africa hold onto trees with their hands while kicking against roots with their feet, emitting powerful sounds that travel long distances, sometimes over a half mile.¬†
‚ÄúThey‚Äôre so fast sometimes‚Ä¶ their hands and fee‚Ä¶

entry.title: This tree's destruction prompted outrage‚Äîand now a guilty verdict
entry.summary:
The Sycamore Gap tree grew in the dip of an ancient Roman wall. A lone tree growing along an ancient Roman wall was a beloved fixture in the landscape. Why did the Sycamore Gap tree‚Äôs illegal felling spark so much emotion?
In the early hours of September 28, 2023, an act of violence and vandalism shocked the U.K.
The next day, news of the attack dominated social media and mainstream news coverage, leading to outpourings of grief, fury at its senselessness, and pilgrimages to the remote stretch of countryside where the crime took place.
This wasn‚Äôt a human tragedy.
In the dark of night, a solitary sycamore tree was cut down at an iconic stretch of an ancient ruin known as Hadrian‚Äôs Wall in Northumberland in north east England. The wall is nearly 2,000 years old and ¬†h‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Alaska volcano might erupt soon
entry.summary:
For the last year, Alaska's Mount Spurr has been showing signs of a potential eruption on the horizon. If an eruption happens, it would likely occur at Crater Peak, shown in the background of this summit photograph.  An explosion on Mount Spurr could generate massive cloud of ash, which could mess with airplanes and cause issues for humans.
Over the past 12 months, an Alaskan volcano named Mount Spurr has become noticeably agitated: It‚Äôs been swelling, quaking, and venting noxious gases. As it stands today, the evidence could point to a major explosive event on the horizon‚Äîor the mountain might just be harmlessly blowing off some steam.
If an eruption were to happen, the good news is that there aren‚Äôt any communities living on its slopes that would be smothered by scaldin‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why do so many animals ‚Äòglow‚Äô in UV light?
entry.summary:
Scorpions are one of many animals that appear to glow under ultraviolet (UV) light. Scientists are finding that photoluminescence is more common than previously suspected.  Animals with ultraviolet color patterns can be found all over nature. Here‚Äôs what we know about what purpose these patterns serve.
Shine an ultraviolet flashlight on flying squirrels, and they glow bright pink. Catch a scorpion on a full moon, and you‚Äôll notice that it‚Äôs a haunting blue. Rays and sharks can turn neon green, while nearby coral come alive in electric reds.
And hawksbill sea turtles? Under ultraviolet light, they turn into glow-in-the-dark, underwater Christmas decorations, with both greens and reds arranged in overlapping chevrons.¬†
Each of these glowing animals is an example o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here‚Äôs your fix of cute baby animals cuddling with their moms
entry.summary:
Photo¬†Ark¬†Babies¬†is Joel Sartore's sixth book exploring the marvels of the animal world through his ongoing National Geographic¬†Photo¬†Ark¬†project, a multi-year mission to¬†photograph animals in human care around the world, emphasizing those liable to be lost forever due to species extinction.
What is family to a seabird who soars alone over the open ocean, or to a primate who clings to its mother for years? Do animals have siblings, aunties, or cousins? Can they survive without any family at all?
Bearing and rearing young are central to the life cycle of nearly all creatures, whether done the way of the giant clam‚Äîby releasing half a billion eggs into the vast sea, full stop‚Äîor the koala, who provides long stretches of intense care. Parents of the animal kingdom are endlessly‚Ä¶

entry.title: Sharing meals could be the key to better mental health
entry.summary:
The cuisines across the Mediterranean, Latin American, and Southeast Asian may vary, but the practice of sharing food and gathering around the table is so deeply rooted in these cultures that it‚Äôs almost sacred. Meals are eaten together, plates are passed with intention, and no one rises until all are finished.
But in other parts of the world, communal dining has become a rarity. The idea of taking a full hour for lunch is met with skepticism, and even basic rituals like sharing a proper meal are brushed aside as indulgent. How has something so essential to our well-being become so easily dismissed?
According to the 2025 World Happiness Report, meal sharing ranks among the strongest predictors of well-being, comparable to factors like income and employment.
(The problem wi‚Ä¶

entry.title: The surprising real world uses of zombie fungi
entry.summary:
Even the largest insect bodies offer no refuge from parasitic fungi. This cicada, now a husk, has been consumed by a fungus. The specimen is part of the growing collection curated by mycologist Jo√£o Ara√∫jo at the University of Copenhagen, where researchers are uncovering the immense diversity‚Äîand potential‚Äîof these microorganisms. Parasitic fungi have adapted to hijack some insects and nourish others. By learning their secrets, we may be able to use them to attack harmful pests.
Zombie fungi have become notorious in pop culture and from videos of them bursting through ants, but it‚Äôs time for their redemption arc.
Scientists know very little about how zombie fungi work, but they and closely related fungi could help farmers kill costly pests like mealybugs and aphids. These pest‚Ä¶

entry.title: What it‚Äôs like to run a marathon beyond the end of the world
entry.summary:
The writer, Nick Busca, crossing the finish line at the Antarctica Marathon. Before you can lace up for one of the world‚Äôs most remote races, you‚Äôll need to navigate wild seas, endure freezing temperatures, and embark on a journey that tests more than just your endurance.
‚ÄúHold on tight. It‚Äôs gonna be wet. And it‚Äôs gonna be bumpy.‚Äù Our Zodiac driver Steven Rose, who goes by Steve, doesn‚Äôt sugarcoat it. I grab the line to my left and slide my goggles over my eyes.
The sea is choppy, and the water is a deep, intense blue that sends chills down my spine. The temperature is around 5¬∞C (41¬∞F), but the 30-knot winds hitting my face make it feel much colder.
As soon as Steve accelerates, the swells hit those at the front of the boat. I grimace: Running a marathon is hard enough ‚Ä¶

entry.title: When elephant moms need help, nannies step in
Why did the Pope pick Leo? Here‚Äôs why the name is so important
entry.summary:
Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost made history by becoming the first Roman Catholic pope from North America. Once elected, however, he chose a pontifical name steeped in hundreds of years of religious tradition: Pope Leo XIV.¬†
As the number indicates, Prevost is the 14th pope with the name Leo. Pope Leo XIV will likely discuss his pontifical name in the coming days, but its significance is clear when looking at the pontificates of his predecessors. From Pope Leo I and his purported exchange with Attila the Hun to Pope Leo IX's role in the Great Schism of A.D. 1054, the pontifical name holds great importance within the Roman Catholic Church.¬†
The name Leo means "lion" in Latin and carries with it a sense of regality, dignity, and leadership. Pope Leo I, the first of three popes in‚Ä¶

entry.title: U.S. Race and Justice Correspondent
entry.summary: Reuters is seeking a skilled and ambitious U.S.-based correspondent to lead coverage on the intersection of race, justice, gender and government. This journalist will pursue stories of global significance that will explore how policy decisions and programs impact communities across the country ‚Äî and the drivers, or people, behind those decisions. As a U.S.-based correspondent [‚Ä¶]

entry.title: OSINT Researcher
entry.summary: CNN is looking for a Researcher to join our Investigations team and will work alongside an ambitious crew of journalists to produce original stories that hold powerful people and institutions accountable, prompt change and right wrongs. The Visual Investigations (OSINT) Researcher will use open-source intelligence techniques to collect, analyze and verify data from publicly available [‚Ä¶]

entry.title: Find your creative side in Toyama's living craft village in Japan
entry.summary:
Surrounded by mountains in central Japan‚Äôs Toyama Prefecture, Inami lives and breathes wood. Out of a population of just 8,000, around 150 people work as woodcarvers and the town is a kind of open-air museum to showcase their skills. In a town hewn from wood, immerse yourself in traditional arts and get hands-on in a craft studio.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Keep your eyes peeled when wandering the stone-paved streets of Inami. The town‚Äôs carpenters, of whom there are many, have tucked dozens of wooden carved cats into unexpected locations, from a svelte feline that doubles as a sweet shop‚Äôs door handle to a pleased-looking puss pouring itself a cup while strategically positioned above a sake shop‚Äôs door. Cat-spotting is just one playful ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Announcing the Sigma Awards 2025 Shortlist
entry.summary: GIJN, the new home of the Sigma Awards, is proud to announce the 2025 shortlist for the best data journalism projects and portfolios in the past year.

entry.title: Fish flee for their lives in rare video of bottom trawling
entry.summary: An aerial view of the impacts of bottom trawling on the ocean floor. The never-before-seen footage of sea creatures struggling in fishing nets is featured in National Geographic‚Äôs new documentary Ocean with David Attenborough. As a cloud of destruction approaches, all the creatures in its path scramble desperately to get out of the way‚Äîfleeing for their lives. However fast they go, they can't outpace it. It looms closer and closer until it swallows them up. Although it may sound like a disaster movie, this is a scene from newly released rare footage of bottom trawling‚Äîa particularly destructive method of fishing in which a ship drags a heavy iron net across the seabed, blindly catching anything in its path. These vessels usually fish for just one species‚Äîcod, haddo‚Ä¶

entry.title: The first U.S. pope? Rome reacts to a once impossible scenario
entry.summary:
Vatican CityAmid the ancient pomp and ceremony of the Vatican, bathed in the gorgeous light of a Roman spring evening, former Cardinal Robert Prevost has emerged onto the balcony of St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica as the first U.S.-born pope in history. He has taken the papal name of Leo XIV‚Äîa name that the vast crowd in St. Peter‚Äôs Square took up with a spontaneous chant of ‚ÄúLe-on-e," the Italian version of the Latin Leo. ¬†
In the hour between the white smoke billowing from a chimney above the Sistine Chapel announcing that the 133 cardinal electors had made their choice shortly after 6 p.m. local time and Leo‚Äôs appearance on the balcony, the streets around the Vatican filled with hurrying crowds, including groups of excited young monks and nuns who gathered up their robes to break into a digni‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to grow from painful experiences
entry.summary:
Erica Solove remembers December 30, 2021, like it was yesterday. She was at home in Superior, Colorado, a Boulder suburb at the foot of the Rockies. ‚ÄúIt was an extremely windy day,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúHurricane-force winds. And we quickly realized it‚Äôs not just wind coming down the mountain ‚Äì it‚Äôs fire.‚Äù She grabbed her napping two-year-old daughter out of her crib while her husband scooped up their five-year-old son. The family got in the car, struggling to open the doors against the wind, and fled without wallets, coats, or even shoes. She remembers how half the sky was black with smoke, while the other half was a bright crystalline blue.
They were fleeing the Marshall Fire, the costliest in Colorado history. Her family lost everything. In the early weeks after the disaster, Solove experien‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why deadly night tornadoes are growing more common
entry.summary:
Tornadoes have long been ranked among the most dangerous weather events in the U.S., but those that strike after dark are significantly more deadly. Nearly twice as fatal as their daytime counterparts, nocturnal tornadoes are becoming more common as a warming climate shifts when and where severe storms form.
The risk is personal for Aaron Hill, a meteorologist and father of three. ‚ÄúI hate nocturnal tornadoes,‚Äù says Hill, who teaches at the University of Oklahoma. Every time a warning sounds at night, he faces the same gut-wrenching decision as many others across the Great Plains: wake the kids, or risk waiting too long.
‚ÄúWe have this battle of, do we wake them up for something not to happen? Do we not wake them up and then rush to get them out? I feel so unprepared,‚Äù he says. ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Nat Geo's ultimate guide to ‚Äòtouching grass‚Äô
entry.summary:
"Touch grass" doesn't have to be an insult. The term is frequently used on social media as a wake-up call to put down your phone and experience the real world‚Äîby, say, relaxing in long grass on a spring day. Science suggests there are serious mental health benefits to touching grass. We're something of an expert in the art of reconnecting with the outdoors. Here‚Äôs our ultimate guide to what the chronically online call ‚Äútouching grass.‚Äù
If you‚Äôre in the mood for a reality check, take a look at how much time you‚Äôve spent staring at your phone this week. We‚Äôll wait‚Ä¶
Are you shocked? Slightly ashamed? Or perhaps inspired to spend less time brain rotting your way into the void?
Well, experts have one piece of advice for you: Touch grass.
Yes, literally. But also metaphori‚Ä¶

entry.title: Deconstructing the Colosseum
entry.summary: To understand the architectural genius of the Colosseum and its symbolic meaning for ancient Rome, it helps to take it apart - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: The ecstatic swoon
entry.summary: As Stendhal knew, the reason for art is to make you feel. Do not try to grasp the artwork: allow it to grasp you instead - by Robert D Zaretsky Read at Aeon

entry.title: How Lanzarote's volcanic landscape has shaped island life
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs just an hour past sunrise when I reach the rim of Caldera Blanca, a steep-sided hulk of igneous rock on the western flank of Lanzarote. The sun casts a reddish wash over the land. Up here ‚Äî some 1,500ft above the broiling swell of the Atlantic ‚Äî the only sounds are the wind and the waves, but the whole island is spread out at my feet. In all directions are dozens of other peaks, silent mounds rising from the jagged flatlands.
Three centuries ago, the summit I‚Äôm standing on didn‚Äôt even exist. In 1730, the ground began belching a morass of ash and lava across the island in a series of cataclysmic eruptions, covering almost a quarter of its entire area. Many villages had to be abandoned for good. The seismic acti‚Ä¶

entry.title: What creatures make these rare ocean gemstones?
entry.summary:
Beneath sea urchins‚Äô¬†exterior spines, rounded skeletons called tests are jewels of color, texture, and symmetry. There are hundreds of urchin species, and they‚Äôre found in every ocean on Earth, from the intertidal zone to more than four miles below the surface. In 2018, Anders Hallan, a research associate at the Australian Museum in Sydney, began photographing urchin skeletons that had washed up on beaches or been collected by divers and those on fishing or research vessels. He created a composite image over the course of a week in 2024 using 76 individual photographs.
The project comes at a perilous moment for these creatures. Since 2022, sea urchins have been plagued by a scuticociliate, a single-celled pathogen that eats away at the animals‚Äô soft tissue and makes their spines fall ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside Kowloon Walled City‚Äîa lawless Hong Kong metropolis
entry.summary:
Until 1994, a tiny subsection of Hong Kong was dominated by a vertical city‚Äîa place so dense, it was hard to imagine how its 30,000 or more residents could survive there.
Known as Kowloon Walled City, the area was littered with trash, cluttered with crime, and renowned for its anarchy. Lawless and largely forgotten by both Chinese and Hong Kong officials, the city ‚Äúhas always aroused curiosity and fear, and few dared venture inside,‚Äù historian Elizabeth Sinn writes in the Journal of the Hong Kong Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society.
But how did Kowloon Walled City become so chaotic‚Äîand why did people choose to live there? Once called the ‚Äúcity of darkness,‚Äù this area was so tangled and contested that its legacy still lives on decades after its eventual destruction. undefine‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here are 5 lesser-known California wine regions worth exploring
entry.summary:
Wine connoisseurs can travel beyond the famed Napa Valley wine region to explore other vineyards like this one in the Santa Ynez Valley, Calif. From the Temecula Valley to the Santa Cruz Mountains, these wine regions deliver more of the tailored experience you seek and less of the crowds.
When it comes to wine tasting in California, most people immediately think of Napa Valley, with its wineries and tasting rooms around every corner. If you look beyond this powerhouse region, you'll find wine destinations across the state, where the weekend traffic isn't as intense and you can get a more personalized wine tasting experience.¬†¬†
Cool winds from the San Francisco Bay flow 90 miles east to the town of Lodi, creating the perfect environment for grape growing. The town owes its ea‚Ä¶

entry.title: These daredevil women pilots helped beat Hitler in WWII
entry.summary:
The women Of Air Transport Auxiliary flew the biggest bombers and the sleekest fighters. Banned from flying in the U.S., these 25 American women headed to Britain to help ferry military aircraft‚Äîand fascinated the public with their free-wheeling lives.
The United States barred women pilots from the armed forces during World War II, but that didn‚Äôt stop 25 courageous young trailblazers. They bolted for Great Britain in 1942 to become the first American women to fly military aircraft.
The pilots have been mostly forgotten ever since. But during the war, they shook things up wherever they landed, prompting headlines like one in the New York Herald Tribune. The pilots, it said, ‚ÄúFly 121 Types of Planes, Sleep Wherever They Land, Find Romance and Tragedy.‚Äù

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 164 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Feb. 24 to March 2, 2025. A total of 5,123 panelists responded out of 5,737 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americans on Healthy Food and Eating
entry.summary: About half of U.S. adults say healthiness of food is important when deciding what to eat. But taste and cost matter more. The post Americans on Healthy Food and Eating appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Are these popular salon treatments a health threat?
entry.summary:
Chemical hair straightening treatments promise smooth, straight hair, but studies have linked them to health issues. Chemical hair straighteners promise smooth, frizz-free hair, but research has linked these treatments to an increased risk of serious health conditions.
A few years ago, strange things began to happen to Merideth Pedack.
The Washington-based hairstylist found she could taste her clients‚Äô deodorant on the back of her tongue, even from ten feet away. A sharp metallic smell clung to her nose throughout the day, and she started getting grinding headaches that seemed to last longer and longer with each passing week until one day they simply never stopped.¬†¬†
‚ÄúThe pounding in my brain and skull and spine and eyes and ears. It was all day. It was all night,‚Äù says ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Views of Race, Policing and Black Lives Matter in the 5 Years Since George Floyd‚Äôs Killing
entry.summary: Roughly seven-in-ten Americans (72%) say the increased focus on race and racial inequality after Floyd‚Äôs killing did not lead to changes that improved the lives of Black people. And 54% say the relationship between Black people and police is about the same as before Floyd was killed. The post Views of Race, Policing and Black Lives Matter in the 5 Years Since George Floyd‚Äôs Killing appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: The UN has renewed its call to end the brutal conflict in Sudan after a surge in drone strikes, including in Port Sudan ‚Äî the vital hub and lifeline for humanitarian aid.

entry.title: New horror in Gaza as double strike on school shelter kills 30
entry.summary: Grim details emerged on Wednesday of Israeli airstrikes on a UN-run school in Gaza sheltering 2,000 displaced people, which reportedly killed 30 Palestinians sheltering there.

entry.title: DR Congo aid operation reaches Beni with food supplies for thousands
entry.summary: A UN food convoy has successfully delivered vital supplies to support tens of thousands of displaced people affected by escalating violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), according to humanitarian teams on the ground.

entry.title: Essential Open Source Tools for Journalists Investigating Air Pollution
entry.summary: Here is a list of open source data tools that journalists can utilize to track air pollution, uncover its sources, and reveal the corporate networks responsible.

entry.title: How to save a desert oasis‚Äîbefore it vanishes completely
entry.summary:
Driving south out of the Atlas Mountains into Morocco‚Äôs Dr√¢a Valley, travelers find that the landscape becomes increasingly stark until the paved national highway vanishes into the desert at the oasis town of Mhamid el Ghizlane.
Sometimes known as the gateway to the Sahara, Mhamid and its surrounding villages are home to about 6,100 people. For generations, the settlement has straddled the Dr√¢a River, with wispy tamarisk trees lining the road on the north bank of the river and palm plantations spreading out to the south. But today the concrete bridge built to span the water rises over a dry riverbed of sand and gravel. Tourists still come to Mhamid, drawn to camel treks, camping, and sandboarding. They arrive by the busload and make their way to hotels that offer swimming pools and ma‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gathering Evidence and Documents in Conflict and War Zones ‚Äî A MENA Case Study
entry.summary: Journalists working in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) are often on the frontlines of unfolding tragedies ‚Äî from Gaza and Sudan to Syria, Yemen to Iraq. In these conflict and post-conflict settings, reporters may be some of the first to encounter potential evidence of war crimes. Their work can go beyond bearing witness [‚Ä¶]

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Center‚Äôs Spring 2024 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates, Social Research Centre and Verian. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Here are more details about our¬†international survey methodology and country-specific [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This analysis was produced by Pew Research Center as part of the Pew-Templeton Global Religious Futures project, which analyzes religious change and its impact on societies around the world. Funding for the Global Religious Futures project comes from The Pew Charitable Trusts and the John Templeton Foundation (grant 63095). This publication does not necessarily reflect [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Religious importance and religious affiliation
entry.summary: By some measures, the world‚Äôs most religious countries are mostly in the Middle East, South and Southeast Asia, sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America. The post 5. Religious importance and religious affiliation appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Spiritual and religious practices
entry.summary: Some activities, such as prayer, are widespread. Others, such as fasting and lighting incense or candles, vary more by country. The post 4. Spiritual and religious practices appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Spells, curses and ways to see the future
entry.summary: Many around the globe think spells or curses can affect people‚Äôs lives. Far fewer say they consult fortune tellers or horoscopes to see the future. The post 3. Spells, curses and ways to see the future appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Beliefs about the afterlife
entry.summary: In nearly every place surveyed, half or more say life after death is likely. Fewer believe in reincarnation or that ancestral spirits can affect their lives. The post 2. Beliefs about the afterlife appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. God, spirits and the natural world
entry.summary: Large majorities around the world say they believe in God. Read about beliefs in spiritual presence ‚Äúbeyond the natural world,‚Äù and in animals and nature. The post 1. God, spirits and the natural world appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Believing in Spirits and Life After Death Is Common Around the World
entry.summary: Belief in an afterlife, God and spirits in nature is widespread globally. Older adults are more likely than younger adults to believe in God. The post Believing in Spirits and Life After Death Is Common Around the World appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Amelia Earhart broke barriers‚Äîuntil her mysterious death
entry.summary:
Amelia Earhart with her airplane. Earhart was an American aviatrix, making history as the first woman to cross Atlantic. From a curious Midwestern girl to a legendary aviator, Amelia Earhart's life was a daring pursuit of freedom, flight, and self-definition. 
  When Amelia Earhart stepped into the cockpit of her Lockheed Electra in June 1937, her sights were set on an accomplishment no woman had ever made‚Äîa female-piloted solo flight around the¬†globe.¬† Newspaper reporters crowded around the plane, documenting everything from her blue eyes to her bobbed hair to her pre-flight banter about her airplane‚Äôs fuel capacity and speed. Though many of the reporters asked about the potential danger of her trip, she shrugged off their questions. ‚ÄúIt is to be a safe and s‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to design a city to improve your mental health
entry.summary:
Designed to enhance accessibility and offer new perspectives, Denmark‚Äôs Camp Adventure Forest Tower draws visitors into the canopy in a way that feels both immersive and restorative. It‚Äôs part of a growing movement to design public spaces that encourage people to gather, linger, and connect. Experts say small changes in our neighborhoods‚Äîlike where we sit, walk, or congregate‚Äîcan make a big difference in how connected we feel to those around us.
Erin Peavey was four months pregnant when she lost her mother to cancer. After her daughter was born in January 2019, the loneliness set in. Her mother had been her rock, a source of steady support. Now, home alone with a newborn and her husband working full time, Peavey clung to a piece of advice her mother had always given her: stay conne‚Ä¶

entry.title: This island has a month-long holiday celebration
entry.summary:
Bermuda celebrates its heritage throughout the month of May, from jazz performances to art showcases to curated historical tours.  Bermuda Day is technically held on the fourth Friday in May, but one day isn‚Äôt really enough to celebrate the island‚Äôs cultural heritage. Here‚Äôs how it began, how it evolved, and how you can take part.
Bermuda Day, a holiday held on the fourth Friday in May each year in Bermuda, kicks off the island's start of summer and marks the rise in water and air temperatures, signaling to Bermudians that it's acceptable to swim in the ocean.
An all-day celebration takes place, not just to signify the warm weather, but to celebrate the island‚Äôs cultural heritage.

entry.title: The best evidence yet that gladiators fought lions: a bite mark
entry.summary:
Artists have long depicted Roman gladiators battling it out against big cats as you can see in this mosaic created in A.D. 320 in Rome. However, there has never been any physical evidence to suggest that this actually happened‚Äîuntil now. For the first time, bite marks made by a large cat, possibly an African lion, have been identified on the bones of what is believed to be an ancient Roman gladiator.
Gladiators fighting lions is among the more enduring images of the arenas of ancient Rome. But other than depictions in mosaics and carvings, along with a few mentions in ancient texts, there is virtually no physical evidence that it actually occurred. Until now.
For the first time, bite marks made by a large cat, possibly an African lion, have been identified on the bones of what‚Ä¶
